results.justification: The paper explicitly states its methodology, focusing on implementing and evaluating Differential Privacy (DP) in Learning Analytics (LA). It outlines the research question and approach in the introduction.
Section 5.2, 'Experiment Procedure', provides a detailed step-by-step description of the experimental design, outlining each stage of the DEFLA framework application.
The paper states the dataset used is the "Open University Learning Analytics Dataset (OULAD) [28]", which is publicly available.
The paper references the original OULAD publication [28], which would contain data documentation. It also mentions the dataset is anonymized and describes the anonymization process (k-anonymity).
While the paper describes the dataset, it does not detail the original data collection methods used by the Open University. It relies on the dataset being pre-collected.
The paper does not mention sharing the analysis code in a repository like GitHub or GitLab.
Since the code is not shared, there are no scripts for data cleaning, analysis, or visualization included.

The paper employs quantitative research methods, including statistical analysis of Utility Loss, Privacy Leakage, and True Revealed Records. It reports values for these metrics and discusses their implications.
The analysis is primarily quantitative. While there is discussion of user communication, it doesn't involve in-depth qualitative data collection or analysis.
The paper does not mention or provide a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
The paper presents the results of the experiment, including figures illustrating Utility Loss, Privacy Leakage, and True Revealed Records, demonstrating the outcomes of applying DP.
Section 5.3.3, 'Limitations', explicitly discusses limitations related to computational complexity, dataset size, and the scope of the LA scenarios tested.
